feed.title: Combined summary - Zero-Conf for Full Node Discovery

entry.title: Combined summary - Zero-Conf for Full Node Discovery
entry.summary: In May 2015, members of the Bitcoin-development mailing list discussed finding a solution for lightweight devices to find a full node on the same LAN to peer with instead of using WAN bandwidth. Matt Whitlock suggested that all nodes should connect solely to a central hub node on the LAN, which should be connected to diverse and unpredictable other nodes on the Bitcoin network. Kevin Greene argued that in order to prevent Sybil attacks, one should choose a set of peers that is diverse and unpredictable.Jim Phillips asked if there was any work being done on using a zero-conf service discovery protocol so that lightweight clients could find a full node on the same LAN to peer with rather than having to tie up WAN bandwidth. Phillips envisioned a future where lightweight devices within a home use SPV over WiFi to connect with a home server which in turn relays the transactions they create out to the larger and faster relays on the Internet. This approach could result in lower traffic across the slow WAN connection, especially in situations where there are hundreds or thousands of small SPV devices in a single home monitoring the blockchain.The discussion also revolves around the technique of seeding address databases via DNS, which can be easily poisoned by controlling the LAN's DNS resolver creating a problematic security issue. Therefore, it was suggested to use a ZeroConf/Rendezvous solution in place so that local LANs can capture Bitcoin traffic away from Tor (with some notification to the user, presumably). This will help people having multiple nodes at home reduce bandwidth and improve sync without difficult setup.Matt Whitlock shared his experience of operating a Bitcoin-only Wi-Fi network at the Porcupine Freedom Festival ("PorcFest") in New Hampshire last summer. He poisoned the DNS and rejected all outbound connection attempts on port 8333 to force all wallets to connect to a single local full node, which had connectivity to a single remote node over the internet. This allowed all the lightweight wallets at the festival to have bitcoin network connectivity while only needing to backhaul the bitcoin network's transaction traffic once.The proposed solution involves pinging the "all nodes" address and trying to connect to TCP port 8333 of each node that responds. The email conversation discusses the possibility of using a zero-conf service discovery protocol to allow lightweight clients to find a full node on the same LAN to peer with instead of tying up WAN bandwidth.Overall, the discussion highlights the importance of creating diverse and unpredictable peer sets to prevent Sybil attacks and finding solutions to reduce bandwidth usage for lightweight devices while still maintaining trust and security.
